ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained incredibly valuable insight into a "canon" of Black political thought and feel that I developed as a thinker.
A deep understanding of the various arguments and perspectives that have come to define black political theory from important authors such as Kimberly Crenshaw to Dubois
I learned how to analyze Black political thought and how to theorize my environments. I also learned why Black political thought and theorizing is so important for the liberation of Black people.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was excellent, and I really don't have anything negative to say. Typically, I would write something about less reading so we can engage more deeply with the material assigned, but I felt that readings chosen for this course were all important and contributed to the overarching discussion. It could be interesting to have more discussion leaders.
This class was amazing the only small request I would make is to lessen the reading load. Given that most of the readings were dense theoretical pieces, it could feel overwhelming some weeks.

The strengths of the course were definitely the readings and the professor. Both were able to provide me with so much information and historical about my surroundings and my identity as a Black person.   Professor Boyd was extremely passionate and this passion made us, as students, want to match his level of passion for theory.

In terms of weaknesses, I would say that sometimes the words Professor Boyd would use were inaccessible. I had a hard time breaking down his feedback at times solely because of the language used.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, but especially those looking to broaden their conception of the "canon" of political theory or those interested specifically in the interventions made by Black intellectuals on the study of liberalism, politics, democracy, society, history, etc. This course could also be a wonderful supplement to what is otherwise an incredibly white curriculum in the political science department so far as political philosophy is concerned. Please continue this course even after Prof. Boyd leaves.

Yes! This has been the most enriching course that I have taken at Yale so far. Each reading has broadened my perspective on issues that impact my daily life. The environment fostered in this seminar allowed for a genuinely free and open discussion in which everyone left the day having contributed and learned something from a peer.

Yes! Black political theory needs to be taught in tandem with the "normal" political theory taught in intro classes because of the radicalized nature of our country. If you want to go into politics or activism I think this class is a must take. The information it provides its students is incredibly valuable and eye opening.
